Hi Jonathan, it's true that most versions of NEAT (maybe all of them) requi=
re positive fitness values.  Of course, one easy way to do that is just to =
scale everything into the positive range.

However, your suggestion of usin=
g a different selection method also can work in principle, though I don't k=
now of specific implementations that have tried that in the past.  But one =
thing you have to be careful about is how exactly the specific implementati=
on of NEAT works because some versions of NEAT (like mine) actually assign =
a number of offspring to each *species* (i.e. not at first to individual ne=
tworks) based on fitness before performing selection *within* the species. =
 In other words, such an implementation would still crash with negative fit=
ness values even with a different selection scheme because the step that as=
signs offspring allotments to each species would not work with negative num=
bers in its equations.  However, that is an artifact of the implementation =
and the principle behind your idea is still theoretically correct and I bel=
ieve it could be implemented that way, but you just have to be careful if y=
ou're using an existing NEAT implementation.

Regarding best-to-worst ratio=
, I'd think more in terms of meaningful differences between substantially d=
ifferent behaviors.  For example, if something that balances a pole for 100=
 seconds has a fitness of 500, then you wouldn't want something that can on=
ly balance the pole for 50 seconds to have a fitness of 490 because it will=
 not make clear enough distinctions for selection to act forcefully.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "jmerlevede"  wrote:
 
 Hi everyone,
 
 I'm a =
graduate student and am currently using NEAT, and hopefully soon HyperNEAT,=
 for my thesis.
 
 After some searching I found out that, after applying fi=
tness sharing and taking elitism into account, NEAT uses fitness proportion=
al selection. This causes some problems for me, because I do not currently =
always generate positive fitness values where the relative fitness of the b=
est and worst individual is 'right'.
 
 I am wondering whether anyone has t=
ried using either tournament selection (instead of proportional selection a=
fter fitness sharing) or some sort of ranking method (as an additional step=
 before fitness sharing), like linear or non-linear ranking. Using any of t=
hese techniques, only the ranking of individuals would become important, an=
d the selection pressure simply becomes another parameter of the algorithm.=

 
 I found some topics about fitness values on this users group, but I did=
 not find one that really addressed my question. I'm sorry if this question=
 has been addressed before.
 
 I would also be happy to hear what you think=
 are good values for the ratio between the fitness of the best and worst in=
dividual and/or the selective pressure and/or the selection intensity.
 
 G=
reetings,
 Jonathan Merlevede
